messageBody:
Cédric,

Jumping back in (I was in at the start then took a rest :-).

On 8/7/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 8/7/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
!snip!
> On one hand, we have a small (very small) population of people who've put
> testing at the forefront of every single engineering task they undertake
> every day at the exclusion of anything else.
!snip!

I think that I'd phrase it that we're trying to build in quality and
that testing is just a tool to help us achieve that end. At the end of
the day, it's all about quality. Now, for some large corporations that
sell shrink wrapped software, the definition of quality involves less
"blue screens of death", while for others it's "no bugs. ever.".

Many things in life are shades of gray and it's obvious that you fall
into that group for quality/testing. I am firmly in the binary camp
(it's tested or it isn't), because to quote myself "unit testing is
the first tollbooth on the road to software quality."

http://simonpeter.org/technology/writings/fourthlaw.html

For me it's all about quality. I think that is where Uncle Bob is
coming from. He cares about quality and he's going to use everything
he has to get there, and TDD is like taking a gun to a knife fight.
Yeah, it might be overkill, but the smart money is going to be on you
to win.

I'm drawn to a parallel example. Indulge me if you will. Consider the
OpenBSD project. Their candy stick is security. Everything they do is
targeted at increasing security. They audit code that has never been
known to cause problems. They go back through the entire code base
every time a new exploit is discovered in any operating system
anywhere. These guys make Uncle Bob look like a slacker (sorry, sir).
Why do they do what they do? Because they care about the quality of
their end product. They have proven that an operating system can be
secure to an insane degree, by default, out of the box. Yet, Microsoft
still brags about "less blue screens of death". Not. Even.Close!

There are many areas of life where close enough is going to work.
Grill your steak for 9 minutes instead of 8 and it's still going to
taste pretty good. But there are some things where anything less than
100% is going to fail. I have a friend that tests flight control
systems for a living. He often explains about how they test code in
his industry when we get together for breakfast. I feel like a slacker
after talking with him. But, aircraft falling out of the sky would be
bad. In his world, "close enough" is "good as dead".

It is vital that as programmers, that we test as much as we can,
because the powers that be, have been known to shutdown testing when
the budget runs out. Your unit tests might be all the testing that
portion of code ever gets. We have no control over anyone else (unless
we're the boss), but as professionals, we can take control of the
quality of the deliverable that we produce.

I'll stop now as there doesn't seem to be much meat left on the horse! :-)

Simon
